title: HMS Dryad (1893)
text:
HMS "Dryad" was the name ship of the <a href="Dryad%20class%20torpedo%20gunboat">"Dryad"-class torpedo gunboats</a>. She was launched at <a href="Chatham%20Dockyard">Chatham Dockyard</a> on 22 November 1893, the first of the class to be completed. She served as a minesweeper during World War I and was broken up in 1920.
Design.
Ordered under the <a href="Naval%20Defence%20Act%201889">Naval Defence Act of 1889</a>, which established <a href="History%20of%20the%20Royal%20Navy%23Two-power%20standard">the "Two-Power Standard"</a>, the class was contemporary with the first <a href="torpedo%20boat%20destroyer">torpedo boat destroyer</a>s. With a length overall of , a beam of and a displacement of 1,070 tons, these torpedo gunboats were not small ships by the standard of the time; they were larger than the majority of World War I destroyers. "Dryad" was engined by Maudslay, Sons & Field with two sets of vertical triple-expansion steam engines, two locomotive-type boilers, and twin screws. This layout produced , giving her a speed of . She carried between 100 and 160 tons of coal and was manned by 120 sailors and officers.
Armament.
The armament when built comprised two <a href="QF%204.7%20inch%20Gun%20Mk%20I%20-%20IV">QF guns</a>, four <a href="QF%206-pounder%20Hotchkiss">6-pounder</a> guns and a single 5-barrelled Nordenfelt machine gun. Her primary weapon was five <a href="British%2018%20inch%20torpedo">18-inch (450-mm) torpedo tubes</a>, with two reloads. On conversion to a minesweeper in 1914 two of the five torpedoes were removed.
Service history.
Mediterranean service.
"Dryad" deployed to <a href="Crete">Crete</a> in February 1897 to operate as part of the <a href="International%20Squadron%20%28Crete%20intervention%2C%201897-1898%29">International Squadron</a>, a multinational force made up of ships of the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Navy">Austro-Hungarian Navy</a>, <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a>, <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a>, Italian Royal Navy ("<a href="Regia%20Marina">Regia Marina</a>"), <a href="Imperial%20Russian%20Navy">Imperial Russian Navy</a>, and Royal Navy that intervened in the 1897-1898 Greek uprising on Crete against rule by the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. On 21 February 1897, she joined the British <a href="battleship">battleship</a> and torpedo gunboat , the Russian battleship "<a href="Russian%20battleship%20Imperator%20Aleksandr%20II">Imperator Aleksandr II</a>", the Austro-Hungarian <a href="armored%20cruiser">armored cruiser</a> , and the German <a href="protected%20cruiser">protected cruiser</a> in the International Squadron′s first direct offensive action, a brief bombardment of Cretan insurgent positions on the heights east of Canea (now <a href="Chania">Chania</a>) after the insurgents refused the squadron′s order to take down a <a href="Flag%20of%20Greece">Greek flag</a> they had raised.
In December 1899, "Dryad" was commissioned for more service on the <a href="Mediterranean%20Station">Mediterranean Station</a>. On 14 January 1900 "Dryad" left <a href="Chatham%20Dockyard">Chatham</a> for the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> in order to relieve , which returned to <a href="HMNB%20Devonport">Devonport</a> to pay off. She was stationed at <a href="Souda%20Bay">Souda Bay</a> until March 1900, when she returned to the station garrison at <a href="Malta">Malta</a>. Later the same month she was posted to <a href="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> as a port ship. On June 1902 she was lent to the <a href="East%20Indies%20Station">East Indies Squadron</a> for special service in the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Aden">Gulf of Aden</a>, returning to Malta in late September.
Tender to the Navigation School.
In 1906 she was chosen as the tender to the Navigation School, conducting navigation training of officers at sea. In due course her name came to be used for the Navigation School itself, and then for <a href="HMS%20Dryad%20%28establishment%29">HMS "Dryad"</a>, the shore establishment at <a href="Southwick%20House">Southwick House</a> in <a href="Hampshire">Hampshire</a>.
On 20 June 1907, "Dryad" rescued the crew of after the <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a> sank without loss of life during afternoon <a href="Steamship">steam</a> <a href="Sea%20trial">trials</a> in the <a href="English%20Channel">English Channel</a> off <a href="Torquay">Torquay</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, when her <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a> broke and punctured her <a href="Hull%20%28ship%29">hull</a>.
Wartime service as a minesweeper.
By 1914 "Dryad" had been converted to a <a href="Minesweeper%20%28ship%29">minesweeper</a> and was operating in the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a> from the port of <a href="Lowestoft">Lowestoft</a>.
Four gunners from "Dryad" were assigned to the <a href="Q-ship">Q-ship</a> <a href="HM%20Armed%20Smack%20Inverlyon">"Inverlyon"</a>. which on 15 August 1915 sank the German submarine with gunfire.
Disposal.
She was renamed "Hamadryad" in 1918 and was sold to H Auten & Co on 24 September 1920 for breaking.
